problem.tex: Define a branch $f(z)$ of $\ln\left(\frac{z-i}{z-1}\right)$ on a region containing $0$. (You should specify the region and define the function explicitly). Find the radius of convergence for the power series expansion of $f(z)$ centered at $z=0$.

solution.tex: The singularity of the Mobius transformation $M(z)=\frac{z-i}{z-1}$ happens at $z=1$, so we will probably not be able to get our radius of convergence to be greater than $1$. Let's see where the unit disc goes under $M$. We have a trace of the unit circle as $1\mapsto i\mapsto -1\mapsto 1$, this maps to the sequence $\infty\mapsto0\mapsto\frac{1}{2}(1+i)\mapsto\infty$. That is, $M$ takes the positively oriented unit circle to the line $y=x$ in $\mathbb{R}^2$ going upwards. Conformal maps preserve orientation, so the disc goes to the upper-left half plane. Then we can define a branch of log on the image under $M$, for $re^{i\theta}=w=\frac{z-i}{z+1}$ we have that $\theta\in(0,2\pi)$ and \[\ln(w)=\ln(r)+e^{i\theta}.\] In terms of $z$ (where $|z|<1$), take $\arg$ to output values in the interval $(0,2\pi)$. Then \[\ln\left(\frac{z-i}{z-1}\right)=\ln\left|\frac{z-i}{z-1}\right|+i\arg\left(\frac{z-i}{z-1}\right).\] There is a pole at $z=1$ for the Mobius transformation and a problem at $z=i$ because log cannot be extended to take in $0$. Therefore our largest ball is the unit disc.
